title: Isaiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 51 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 51.

questions.question: To whom does Isaiah 51:2 ask us to look as our father and mother?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:2 specifically says to look unto Abraham your father, and unto Sarah that bare you.

questions.question: What will the LORD make the wilderness like, according to Isaiah 51:3?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:3 states that the LORD will make her wilderness like Eden.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 51:6, what will happen to the heavens?
options: They shall vanish away like smoke
They shall fall to the earth
They shall be covered with darkness
questions.correctAnswer: They shall vanish away like smoke
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:6 says the heavens shall vanish away like smoke.

questions.question: Who does Isaiah 51:12 say comforts the people and asks why they should fear man?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:12 says 'I, even I, am he that comforteth you' referring to the LORD.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 51:9 call on the arm of the LORD to do?
options: Awake as in the ancient days
questions.correctAnswer: Awake as in the ancient days
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:9 calls on the arm of the LORD to awake as in the ancient days.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 51:10, what did the LORD do to the sea?
options: Dried the sea and made a way for the ransomed to pass
questions.correctAnswer: Dried the sea and made a way for the ransomed to pass
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:10 describes how the LORD dried the sea, making a way for the ransomed to pass over.

questions.question: In Isaiah 51:11, what will the redeemed of the LORD do when they return?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:11 states the redeemed of the LORD shall return and come with singing unto Zion.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 51:15 say is the name of the LORD?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:15 declares that The LORD of hosts is his name.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 51:17, what has Jerusalem drunk at the hand of the LORD?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:17 says Jerusalem has drunk the cup of his fury.

questions.question: Who is described as fainted and lying at the head of all the streets in Isaiah 51:20?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:20 describes thy sons as fainted and lying at the head of all the streets.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 51:7 encourages the people not to fear the reproach of men or their revilings.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:7 says 'fear ye not the reproach of men, neither be ye afraid of their revilings.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 51:13 reminds the people to forget the LORD their maker.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:13 asks 'And forgettest the LORD thy maker?' implying they should not forget Him.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 51:22 promises the cup of trembling will be taken from the hand of the afflicted.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:22 states God has taken out of their hand the cup of trembling.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Isaiah 51:1: 'Look unto the rock whence ye are _______'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:1 says 'look unto the rock whence ye are hewn.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Isaiah 51:16: 'And I have put my words in thy _______'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:16 states 'And I have put my words in thy mouth.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 51 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear because of others' harsh words and reproach. Based on Isaiah 51, what biblical truth would you share about dealing with fear and reproach?
options: Fear not the reproach of men, for my righteousness and salvation endure forever
Hide from others to avoid reproach
Seek revenge against those who revile you
Ignore all counsel and rely only on your own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not the reproach of men, for my righteousness and salvation endure forever
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:7 and 51:8 teach believers not to fear reproach or revilings of men because God's righteousness and salvation are everlasting, providing comfort and confidence. These verses emphasize trusting God's eternal justice and salvation rather than human judgment.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 51 teach us about God's faithfulness in our trials and suffering?
options: God comforts Zion and turns her wilderness into a joyful garden
Suffering is permanent and without hope
We must rely only on ourselves during trials
questions.correctAnswer: God comforts Zion and turns her wilderness into a joyful garden
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:3 promises that the LORD will comfort Zion, transforming her desolate places into joy and gladness like Eden. This assures believers that God is faithful to bring restoration and joy after suffering, encouraging perseverance and hope.

questions.question: A believer is feeling hopeless about the future due to the world's instability. What encouragement about God's salvation can you share from Isaiah 51?
options: God's salvation is forever and His righteousness will never be abolished
The world will always remain as it is
Salvation depends on personal effort only
Nothing lasts forever, including God's promises
questions.correctAnswer: God's salvation is forever and His righteousness will never be abolished
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:6 and 51:8 emphasize that while the heavens and earth may perish, God's salvation and righteousness endure forever, offering believers unshakable hope and security beyond temporal troubles.

questions.question: What biblical principle about trusting God's justice is taught in Isaiah 51 when facing oppression and injustice?
options: God's arm will judge the people and the nations will wait upon Him
We must take justice into our own hands
questions.correctAnswer: God's arm will judge the people and the nations will wait upon Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:5 explains that God's salvation has gone forth and His arm will judge the people; the isles (nations) will wait on Him. This teaches believers to trust God's righteous judgment rather than resorting to personal revenge.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the fading of earthly things. What does Isaiah 51 say about the eternal nature of God's promises?
options: Heavens will vanish but God's salvation remains forever
Earth's beauty is eternal and unchanging
questions.correctAnswer: Heavens will vanish but God's salvation remains forever
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:6 reminds us that although the heavens and earth will fade like a garment, God's salvation and righteousness endure eternally, assuring believers of lasting hope beyond earthly decay.

questions.question: In what way does Isaiah 51 suggest believers should respond when feeling weak and discouraged?
options: Awake and put on strength, trusting in the LORD as in ancient days
questions.correctAnswer: Awake and put on strength, trusting in the LORD as in ancient days
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:9 calls the 'arm of the LORD' to awake and put on strength as in ancient days, encouraging believers to trust God's power and renew their spiritual strength during discouragement.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 51 teach about God's role as comforter for His people?
options: God Himself comforts His people and calls them not to fear mortal man
Comfort comes only from friends and family
One must comfort oneself without God
Comfort is not available in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God Himself comforts His people and calls them not to fear mortal man
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:12 shows God saying 'I am he that comforteth you,' encouraging believers not to fear men who die like grass, highlighting God's unique and eternal comfort.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 51, what should a believer remember about their spiritual heritage and identity?
options: Look unto Abraham and Sarah as your spiritual ancestors
Your identity is solely based on your achievements
You have no connection to past believers
questions.correctAnswer: Look unto Abraham and Sarah as your spiritual ancestors
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:1-2 urges believers to look to Abraham and Sarah, their spiritual fathers and mothers, who were called and blessed by God, grounding their identity in God's promises and faithfulness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 51, God's word is given as a law and judgment to be a light for the people.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:4 states that a law shall proceed from God and His judgment will be a light to the people, emphasizing the guiding role of God's word in believers' lives.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 51 teaches that the cup of God's fury will be removed from His people and given to their oppressors.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:22-23 explains that God will take the cup of trembling from His people and give it to those who afflict them, showing God's justice and deliverance for His people.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Therefore the redeemed of the LORD shall return, and come with ______ unto Zion; and everlasting joy shall be upon their head."
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:11 says the redeemed of the LORD will return with singing, symbolizing joy and gladness replacing sorrow and mourning.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 51 teach about the importance of trusting God's power in deliverance?
options: God dried the sea to make a path for the redeemed
Deliverance depends on human strength alone
God does not intervene in difficult situations
One should avoid trusting God in hardships
questions.correctAnswer: God dried the sea to make a path for the redeemed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:10 recounts God's mighty act of drying the sea to provide a way for the ransomed to pass, teaching believers to trust God's power to deliver them from trials.

questions.question: What practical lesson about spiritual discipline and obedience can be learned from Isaiah 51?
options: God places His words in our mouths and covers us with His hand
God does not guide our words or actions
questions.correctAnswer: God places His words in our mouths and covers us with His hand
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:16 affirms God puts His words in the believer’s mouth and covers them with His hand, highlighting the importance of obedience and reliance on God for guidance and protection.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 51 encourage believers to respond when feeling abandoned and desolate?
options: Awake, stand up, and remember God’s past faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Awake, stand up, and remember God’s past faithfulness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:17 calls Jerusalem to awake and stand up despite drinking the cup of fury, encouraging believers to rise in faith, trusting God’s enduring faithfulness through trials.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 51 teach about the believer’s attitude towards God’s law and righteousness?
options: The law is a light for the people and righteousness is near
The law should be ignored for personal preference
The law is a burden with no guidance
questions.correctAnswer: The law is a light for the people and righteousness is near
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:4-5 teaches that God's law proceeds from Him as a judgment and light for the people, and His righteousness is near, encouraging believers to obey and trust His ways.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 51.

questions.question: In Isaiah 51:1, the people are urged to look unto the 'rock whence ye are hewn.' What does this metaphor most likely represent in the context of ancient Near Eastern covenant theology?
options: Their ancestral origins and God as their foundation
A literal rock formation in the land of Israel
A pagan idol worshiped by the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Their ancestral origins and God as their foundation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:1 uses 'rock' as a metaphor for the foundation from which the people were hewn, symbolizing God as their origin and source of strength, consistent with covenant imagery in the Hebrew Bible.

questions.question: Isaiah 51:3 describes the LORD making Zion's wilderness like Eden. Which literary device is primarily used in this verse to convey hope and restoration?
questions.explanation: The phrase 'like Eden' in Isaiah 51:3 is a simile comparing Zion's future restoration to the Garden of Eden, expressing an ideal of divine blessing and renewal.

questions.question: The phrase 'my righteousness is near; my salvation is gone forth' in Isaiah 51:5 can be seen as a foreshadowing of which New Testament theme?
options: The coming of Jesus as the righteous Savior
The destruction of Jerusalem in 70 AD
The establishment of the Mosaic Law
questions.correctAnswer: The coming of Jesus as the righteous Savior
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:5 anticipates the arrival of God's salvation and righteousness, a theme taken up in the New Testament regarding Jesus’ redemptive work.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 51:6, what is the contrast between the heavens and earth versus God's salvation and righteousness?
options: The heavens and earth will perish, but God's salvation is eternal
The heavens and earth are eternal, but God's salvation is temporary
Both the heavens and God's salvation will vanish
God's righteousness will be abolished like the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The heavens and earth will perish, but God's salvation is eternal
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:6 contrasts the temporal nature of creation with the everlasting nature of God's salvation and righteousness.

questions.question: In Isaiah 51:7, the people are instructed not to fear reproach or revilings. This encouragement is best understood in light of which historical context?
options: Exile and persecution of Israel by foreign powers
The building of the first temple
questions.correctAnswer: Exile and persecution of Israel by foreign powers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:7 addresses the faithful in a context of suffering and reproach, likely during or prior to the Babylonian exile when Israel faced oppression.

questions.question: The call to 'awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the LORD' in Isaiah 51:9 is an example of what type of Hebrew poetic device?
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase 'awake, awake' at the beginning of the verse is an example of anaphora, a literary device to emphasize urgency and strength.

questions.question: Isaiah 51:10 references drying the sea and making a way for the ransomed to pass over. Which Old Testament event does this allusion primarily recall?
options: The Exodus crossing of the Red Sea
The Jordan River crossing under Joshua
questions.correctAnswer: The Exodus crossing of the Red Sea
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:10 alludes to God's deliverance of Israel through the parting of the Red Sea during the Exodus, a foundational act of salvation.

questions.question: The 'cup of trembling' mentioned in Isaiah 51:17 and 51:22 symbolizes what in the prophetic and ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.explanation: The 'cup of trembling' in Isaiah symbolizes God's fierce judgment and the experience of divine wrath poured out on Jerusalem.

questions.question: Isaiah 51:12 poses a rhetorical question about fearing a man who shall die. How does this verse reflect a theological contrast between God and humanity found throughout Scripture?
options: God is eternal and sovereign, while humans are mortal and transient
God is weak and dependent, while humans are immortal
Humans are divine beings, while God is a created entity
Both God and humans share equal power
questions.correctAnswer: God is eternal and sovereign, while humans are mortal and transient
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:12 emphasizes God's eternal nature contrasted with human mortality, encouraging trust in God rather than fear of men.

questions.question: Which term in Isaiah 51:15 emphasizes God's mighty power over the chaotic waters, a common ancient Near Eastern symbol for chaos?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:15 identifies God as the LORD who divided the sea, demonstrating his sovereign power over the chaotic waters, a frequent symbol for chaos in ancient Near Eastern literature.

questions.question: What is the significance of God placing 'words in thy mouth' in Isaiah 51:16 in light of the prophetic calling?
options: It signifies divine commissioning and authority to speak God's message
It indicates a loss of personal speech
It refers to a written law on stone tablets
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies divine commissioning and authority to speak God's message
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:16 refers to God empowering the prophet with words, a common biblical theme signifying divine commissioning to proclaim God's judgment and comfort.

questions.question: Isaiah 51:19 mentions 'desolation, destruction, famine, and the sword.' How do these elements collectively reflect the historical realities faced by Jerusalem?
options: They depict the calamities of siege and exile experienced by the city
They describe natural disasters unrelated to human actions
They refer to a future utopian peace
questions.correctAnswer: They depict the calamities of siege and exile experienced by the city
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:19 lists calamities that reflect the historical suffering of Jerusalem during invasions, sieges, and exile in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: True or False: In Isaiah 51:11, the redeemed of the LORD are described as returning to Zion with sorrow and mourning.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:11 states that the redeemed come with singing and everlasting joy, and that sorrow and mourning shall flee away, indicating a reversal of suffering.

questions.question: The motif of 'everlasting joy' in Isaiah 51:11 is echoed in which New Testament passage emphasizing the eschatological hope of God's people?
questions.explanation: Revelation 21:4 speaks of God wiping away tears and the end of death and sorrow, paralleling Isaiah 51:11’s promise of everlasting joy for the redeemed.

questions.question: Isaiah 51:14 refers to the captive exile hastening to be loosed. Which historical event does this likely reference?
options: The Babylonian exile and anticipation of release
The splitting of the Red Sea
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile and anticipation of release
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:14 reflects the experience of Israelites in Babylonian captivity longing for liberation, a central theme in prophetic literature.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 51 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 51:1, what are the people called to 'look unto' as the source of their origin?
options: The rock whence ye are hewn
questions.correctAnswer: The rock whence ye are hewn
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:1 calls the righteous to look unto 'the rock whence ye are hewn,' indicating God as the foundational source of their being. This echoes Psalm 18:2 where God is called 'my rock and my fortress,' and 1 Corinthians 10:4 where Christ is described as the spiritual rock.

questions.question: In Isaiah 51:3, what transformation does the LORD promise for Zion’s waste places?
options: He will make her wilderness like Eden
He will flood her fields with water
He will build a new temple
He will cover her in darkness
questions.correctAnswer: He will make her wilderness like Eden
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:3 promises that the LORD will comfort Zion and transform her wilderness like Eden, symbolizing restoration and joy. This theme is consistent with Ezekiel 36:35 and Revelation 21:1-4 where desolation is replaced with divine renewal and joy.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 51:4 identify as proceeding from God for the people?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:4 states that 'a law shall proceed from me,' showing God's sovereign authority to establish righteous judgment as a light to the peoples. This aligns with Psalm 119:105 and John 1:17 where the law and grace come from God to guide His people.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 51:5, what will judge the people?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:5 declares that 'mine arms shall judge the people,' emphasizing God's power and righteous judgment. This divine arm imagery is echoed in Exodus 15:16 and Romans 8:34 where God's mighty hand delivers and judges.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 51:6 describe the permanence of God's salvation compared to the heavens and earth?
options: The heavens and earth will last longer
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:6 contrasts the transient nature of the heavens and earth with the eternal permanence of God's salvation. This eternal salvation theme is consistent with Psalm 119:89, Hebrews 13:8, and 1 Peter 1:24-25.

questions.question: Who are exhorted in Isaiah 51:7 to not fear the reproach or revilings of men?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:7 exhorts those who know righteousness and have God's law in their hearts not to fear human reproach. This encouragement resembles Jesus' teaching in Matthew 5:10-12 and Paul’s exhortation in Romans 8:31.

questions.question: Which ancient enemies does God call upon to 'awake' and 'put on strength' in Isaiah 51:9?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:9 calls the 'arm of the LORD' to awake as in ancient days, recalling God's past mighty acts like defeating Rahab and the dragon, symbolic of chaotic powers. This reflects God’s sovereign power described in Psalm 89:10 and Job 26:12.

questions.question: What did God do to the 'waters of the great deep' according to Isaiah 51:10?
options: Dried the sea to make a path for the ransomed
questions.correctAnswer: Dried the sea to make a path for the ransomed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:10 recounts God's miraculous act of drying the sea to provide a path for the redeemed, alluding to the Exodus crossing of the Red Sea. This demonstrates God's saving power, as seen also in Exodus 14 and Psalm 66:6.

questions.question: What is the emotional state of the redeemed when they return to Zion as stated in Isaiah 51:11?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:11 describes the redeemed returning with singing and everlasting joy, showing the joy of salvation. This joyful restoration aligns with Psalm 126:2-3 and Revelation 7:9-10.

questions.question: In Isaiah 51:12, who declares Himself as the one who comforts His people?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:12 highlights God’s personal role as the comforter of His people, emphasizing His unique divine identity. This is consistent with God’s self-revelation in Isaiah 43:1-2 and Jesus’ promise to comfort in John 14:16.

questions.question: What question does God ask in Isaiah 51:13 to rebuke fear of man and oppression?
options: And where is the fury of the oppressor?
questions.correctAnswer: And where is the fury of the oppressor?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:13 challenges fear of oppressive men by questioning the power of their fury, pointing to God's sovereignty. This rhetorical question echoes Psalm 37:12-13 and Romans 8:31 which affirm God's ultimate control over oppressors.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 51:15, who is named as the one that divided the sea and whose waves roared?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:15 identifies 'The LORD thy God' as the one who divided the sea, affirming His power over creation and salvation history, consistent with Exodus 14:21-22 and Psalm 77:16-20.

questions.question: In Isaiah 51:16, what does God say He has put in the mouth of His servant?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:16 states God has put His words in the servant’s mouth, indicating divine inspiration and authority for proclamation. This is affirmed in Jeremiah 1:9 and Luke 4:18 where God’s word empowers prophetic ministry.

questions.question: What has Jerusalem drunken from the hand of the LORD according to Isaiah 51:17?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:17 describes Jerusalem as having drunk 'the cup of his fury,' symbolizing divine judgment and discipline. This metaphor is also used in Psalm 75:8 and Revelation 14:10 concerning God’s righteous judgment.

questions.question: Isaiah 51:22 promises that God has taken from the afflicted the cup of trembling. What will happen to this cup?
options: It shall no more be drunk by them
It will be poured out on Jerusalem
It will be filled with joy
It shall be given to their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: It shall no more be drunk by them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 51:22 promises that God has taken the cup of trembling from His people and that they will not drink it again, signifying an end to their suffering. This hope parallels Psalm 116:13 and Revelation 21:4 where pain and sorrow cease.
